summary: This document is a summary of a call between Assistant United States Attorneys (AUSAs) and Dr. Rocchio, a forensic and clinical psychologist, on February 1, 2021. Dr. Rocchio outlines his expertise in trauma, child sexual abuse, grooming, delayed reporting, and complex trauma, but clarifies he has not treated any victims of Jeffrey Epstein or been involved in any related litigation. The call appears to be an exploratory consultation regarding potential expert testimony.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: Consulted by AUSAs regarding his expertise in trauma, child sexual abuse, grooming, and delayed reporting. He clarifies he has not treated any Jeffrey Epstein victims or been involved in any related litigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'JE' in the document. The subject of the case for which the AUSAs are consulting an expert. His victims are mentioned as a potential subject of inquiry.

connections.description: Dr. Rocchio is being consulted by AUSAs regarding his psychological expertise, potentially for the Jeffrey Epstein case.

events.title: Consultation Call with Dr. Rocchio
events.description: Assistant United States Attorneys hold a call with forensic psychologist Dr. Rocchio to discuss his expertise in trauma, child sexual abuse, grooming, and delayed reporting, in the context of the Jeffrey Epstein case.

locations: One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Dr. Rocchio, a forensic and clinical psychologist, explicitly states he has not treated any victims of Jeffrey Epstein (JE) or been involved in any JE-related litigation.
Dr. Rocchio's expertise includes child sexual abuse grooming, delayed reporting, trauma bonding/attachment, complex trauma, and incremental disclosure of memories by victims.
The consultation appears to be an effort by federal prosecutors (AUSAs) to potentially identify or vet an expert witness for aspects of the Epstein case.
Dr. Rocchio notes that in cases of child sexual abuse, non-participating parents can be considered 'non-offending,' while those who facilitate abuse are perpetrators.
The document is a summary memo from the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
